2: A disease in which abnormal cells divide uncontrollably and destroy body tissue. Some genetic changes causes cells to divide uncontrollably and provides ability to the cells to spread to other locations and destroys them.
3: When cells divide uncontrollably in Breast and have ability to spread outside the Breast to other organs and destory the surround tissue is called Breast Cancer. If not treated, it can spread and destroy important organs and cause death.
4:
A tumor or lump is any abnormal mass of tissue or swelling. Like a cyst, a tumor can form in any part of the body. A tumor can be benign or cancerous (malignant), A benign tumor has distinct, smooth, regular borders. A malignant tumor has irregular borders and grows faster than a benign tumor. 
 A malignant tumor can also spread to other parts of your body. A benign tumor can become quite large, but it will not invade nearby tissue or spread to other parts of your body.
5: A cyst is a sac that may be filled with air, fluid or other material. A cyst can form in any part of the body, including bones, organs and soft tissues. Most cysts are noncancerous (benign), but sometimes cancer can cause a cyst.
6: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the presence of abnormal cells inside a milk duct in the breast. DCIS is considered the earliest form of breast cancer. DCIS is noninvasive, meaning it hasn't spread out of the milk duct.  However the cells can bcome invasive in due time can spread to other organs. Hence It should be treated by consulting a Oncologist/OncoSurgen. The positive news is that if you have only DCIS without Invasive componenet, the 10 year survival rate is 98%, however if you are diagonized  with DCIS, you will need fequent monitoring  even after treatment as your risk of cancer increases if you had DCIS.
7:
If the cancer is very much localized to the only tissue where it originated and not spread to nearby tissue. The cancer is called in-situ. It is a precursor of cancer.
Surger and/or radiation therapy is treatment option of such type of cancer
8: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is the presence of abnormal cells inside a milk lobules in the breast. LCIS is considered the earliest form of breast cancer. LCIS is noninvasive, meaning it hasn't spread out of the milk duct.  However the cells can bcome invasive in due time can spread to other organs. Hence It should be treated by consulting a Oncologist/OncoSurgen. The positive news is that if you have only LCIS without Invasive componenet, the 10 year survival rate is 98%, however if you are diagonized  with LCIS, you will need fequent monitoring  even after treatment as your risk of cancer increases if you had LCIS.
9:
The aim of palliative treatment is to relieve symptoms and improve your quality of life. It can be used at any stage of an illness even with curative treatment if there are troubling symptoms, such as pain or sickness. In advanced cancer, palliative treatment might help someone to live longer and more comfortably, even if they cannot be cured
Chemo, radiation and surgery can be suggested as part of palliative treatment
10: Curative treatment is given to cure the cancer, which is even recommed many times are first choice of treatment even in stage 4 cancer patients.
11: A biopsy is a procedure to remove a piece of tissue or a sample of cells from your body so that it can be tested in a laboratory. In Aspiration biopsy a syringe is inserted to draw out some cells and those cells are checked under microscope. In USG guided biosy an ultrasonography machine is used to check the tumor and a neddle is inserted to draw some pieces of tumor to analyze under microsope
12: Breast Cancer at early stages(1&2) can be cured in most of the cases. Many people have even completely cured of stage 3 Breat cancer. Even in advance stages, there are lots of treatment available, with the advancement in cancer treatment in recent years, patients can live a long life if they cannot be complety cured
13: Anyone can get  Breast Cancer, however chances of getting Breast cancer are more if you or your first degree family memeber had history of Invasive or In situ Breast cancer
14:
Surgery is the main form of treatment, if there is not much spread of cancer in body, Surgery will be done first(Mestactomy or Lumpactomy)
Followed by Chemotherapy and Radiation. Sometimes chemo and Radition will be given together. Sometimes Radition may not be given depending on age and type of cancer. In case of advance or stage 4 cases, Chemo is usually recommend before surgery
15:
If the cancer is in-situ with no invasive component its called stage 0 or precancer
If cancer is invasive that it as move to nearby breast tissue other than where it originated but has size less than 2 cm and not spread to other organs or lymp node its called stage 1.
If the cancer is more than 2 cm but not invaded lymp node and is invasive its called stage 2, if the cancer has invaded lymp node but not spread to other organs its called stage 3 and if the cancer has spread to other organs its called stage 4
16:
If cancer has spread to other organs, other than where it originated it is called stage 4 or metastatic cancer, first metastatic location for breast cancer is usually lung and ribs, however it can go to liver, brain and other tissues.
Usually cure at this stage is not possible(However now a days doctors provide curative treatment if cancer is spread to few places'oligo-metastatic'). However with the advancement in cancer treatment in recent years, patients can live a long life if they cannot be complety cured. Palliative treatment is provided to ease pain of patient
17:
A type of metastasis in which cancer cells from the original (primary) tumor travel through the body and form a small number of new tumors (metastatic tumors) in one or two other parts of the body.
Oligometastatic breast cancer is a subgroup of patients with MBC who have good long term survival raising the tantalizing possibility of 'functional cure'. However, it is still uncertain whether these 'cures' are due to selection of patients with favorable disease biology versus 'aggressive' local or systemic therapeutic interventions
18:
If caught early nearly 99% of Breast cancer can be cured, hence its very important to do Breast Checkups.
 If the cancer is localized 5-yrs survival rate is 99%/
If the cancer is regional and  spread to lymp node the survival rate is 86% and if the cancer is spread  to other organs the survival rate is 29%.
 The above figures do not distinguish between different type of Breast caners. The prognosis depends on cancer types as well.
19: Cancer cells can have hormone receptors, that is hormones might fuel the growth of cancer cels, if there are Estrogen hormone receptor they are called ER Positive Cancers, if there are Progestrone hormone receptors they are called PR positive cancer, There are more treatment options available or ER/PR positive cancer and becaue of this these types of cancer have better prognosis when compared to ER/PR negative cancers
20:
A mammogram is an X-ray picture of the breast.
Doctors use a mammogram to look for early signs of breast cancer.
 Regular mammograms are the best tests doctors have to find breast cancer early, sometimes up to three years before it can be felt.
 Discomfort during a mammogram procedure varies from patient to patient.
 Some experience discomfort due to the compression that is applied to the breast. Most women, however, tolerate the exam quite well. If required, somtimes momography is followed by Sonomammography (Ultrasound of Breast) Sonomammography or ultrasound of the breast is a non-invasive procedure performed to check the health of breasts and the blood flow to areas inside it.
It is an imaging technique that is used to examine and screen for cancer or/and other breast abnormalities. Sonomammography is a painless procedure
21: Lymphovascular invasion (LVI) is defined as the presence of tumor cells within a definite endothelial-lined space (lymphatics or blood vessels) in the breast surrounding invasive carcinoma. The presence of LVI is associated with an increased risk of axillary lymph node and distant metastases.
22: Side effects of cancer treatment are different for different patients. Majority of patient get no other symtoms other than hair fall, however some patients have reported following side effects: nausea/vomiting diarrhea constipation pain arm swelling shortness of breath skin irritation Patients might feel tired soon after surgery or chemo. However patients should feel better as days pass.
23: Triple-positive breast tumors are HER2-positive, ER-positive, and PR-positive. These cancers are treated with hormone drugs as well as drugs that target HER2, their agressiveness depends of the grade or cancer. Usually they are not agressive. Their prognosis is better compared to tripple negatiev and HER2+ve cancers of the same stage
24: Triple-negative breast cancer is that which tests negative for three receptors: estrogen, progesterone, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). It is also the least common form of breast cancer and the hardest to treat as it doesn't have any receptors, so treatments cannot be given targatig the receptors. They are mostly agressive, however they can be mostly cured if detected early. In Recent times new immunotherapy medicines  have shown great benifitis for advace stage tripple -ve breast cancer for some patients
25:
HER2-positive breast cancer is a breast cancer that tests positive for a protein called human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). This protein promotes the growth of cancer cells. In about 1 of every 5 breast cancers, the cancer cells have extra copies of the gene that makes the HER2 protein.
Treatment is similar to other cancers, however drugs targeting HER2 receptors are also given as part of the cancer treatment
26: A low grade number (grade 1) usually means the cancer is slower-growing and less likely to spread. A high grade number (grade 3) means a faster-growing cancer that's more likely to spread. An intermediate grade number (grade 2) means the cancer is growing faster than a grade 1 cancer but slower than a grade 3 cancer.
27:
Papilloma is not a cancer and is very unlikely to develop into a cancer. But the cells of the papilloma should be examined under the microscope after it has been removed.
Solitary papillomas (solitary intraductal papillomas) are single tumors that often grow in the large milk ducts near the nipple. They are a common cause of clear or bloody nipple discharge, especially when it comes from only one breast. They may be felt as a small lump behind or next to the nipple.
28: Breast sarcomas are rare, histologically heterogeneous nonepithelial malignancies that arise from the connective tissue within the breast. They can develop de novo (primary), after radiation therapy (RT), or in the setting of chronic lymphedema of the arm or breast (therapy-related, secondary)
29:
The main symptom of lymphedema after breast cancer treatment is swelling of the arm on the side where lymph nodes have been removed. The amount of swelling may vary. Some people may have severe swelling (edema) with the affected arm being several inches larger than the other arm.
 Breast lymphedema occurs because of damage to the lymphatic system. it typically happens as a result of cancer, surgery for cancer or radiation. It's also not limited to the breast but can occur in the chest area and the armpit as well.
Patient should protect the hand adjacent to the operated breast.
There are excerizes suggested after breast cancer. Many a times Lymphoedema Stockings are recommeded by doctors. Please consult onco-surgeons if you have Lymphoedema
30: Atypical hyperplasia is a precancerous condition that affects cells in the breast. Atypical hyperplasia describes an accumulation of abnormal cells in the milk ducts and lobules of the breast. Atypical hyperplasia isn't cancer, but it increases the risk of breast cancer.It is treated surgically
31:
'Usual hyperplasia' means there is excessive growth of benign cells in an area of the breast, but the cells donâ€™t look abnormal. This can happen along the inner lining of the breast duct (tube that carries milk to the nipple) or the lobule (small round sac that produces milk).This information is provided by Breastcancer.org.
Usual ductal hyperplasia is considered a normal finding in the breast and does not need to be treated.
32:
Breast cancer can recur even after sucessfull treatment. It can even recur at different location other than the breast(Chances of distant recurrance depend on what stage the earlier cancer was detected and treated).
There are cases where breast cancer has recured in same othe the other breast even after 5,10 15, 20 years after the first cancer was treated, so consistent followups to doctor are required.
33: Breast self-exam, or regularly examining your breasts on your own, can be an important way to find a breast cancer early, when it's more likely to be treated successfully. More info can be found at https://www.breastcancer.org/screening-testing/breast-self-exam-bse

 If you feel depressed or are suffering from anxity it is very important to take help from psychotherapist

No one can escape death even if the person doesn't have cancer. Having said that, there has been lot of research in last few decades on Breast Cancer, new mediciens have come in the market, more trails are going on.
5-year survival rate for Breast cancer in high income countries is 90% In India it is 66% and is Increasing. There are patients who have are living with metastatic breast cancer for more than 20 years.
 If you feel depressed or are suffering from anxity it is very important to take help from psychotherapist to provide appropriate treatment.

38:
Major Breast Cancer symptoms are
1. New lump in the breast or underarm (armpit). 
2.Thickening or swelling of part of the breast.
3.Irritation or dimpling of breast skin.
4.Redness or flaky skin in the nipple area or the breast.
5.Pulling in of the nipple or pain in the nipple area or inverted nipple.
6.Nipple discharge other than breast milk, including blood.
7.Any change in the size or the shape of the breast.
8.Pain in any area of the breast.

Keep in mind that these symptoms can happen with other conditions that are not cancer.
however If you have any signs or symptoms that worry you, be sure to see your doctor right away.In Few case it can happen that there might be a non-palpable lump which might be cancerous but can only be detected using sono or mamogram, in case you are at risk of cancer or have BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation or family history of Breast cancer consult your physician to get you checked using Sono or Mammogram
39:
Chemotherapy is cancer treatment with drugs, unlike surgery which is performed on a site, chemo targets all the cells which might be spread to different locations but are not visible to scanning devices. Chemotherapy has variety of side effects like hair loss, Nausea, vomiting, decrease in platelet count, but not all symptoms are seen for all individuals, most common symptom is hair loss.
Now a day There are new chemo drugs which have less side effects.
40: Immunotherapy is a newer form of treatment which helps your immune system to kill cancer cells. 15-20% of patients achieve durable results with immunotherapy even for advance stages.
41:
There are multiple types of Breast Cancers:
1.Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS): Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS; also known as intraductal carcinoma) is a non-invasive or pre-invasive breast cancer.
2.Invasive breast cancer (ILC or IDC): Invasive (or infiltrating) breast cancer has spread into surrounding breast tissue. The most common types are invasive ductal carcinoma and invasive lobular carcinoma. Invasive ductal carcinoma makes up about 70-80% of all breast cancers.
3.Triple-negative breast cancer: Triple-negative breast cancer is an aggressive type of invasive breast cancer in which the cancer cells donâ€™t have estrogen or progesterone receptors (ER or PR) and also donâ€™t make any or too much of the protein called HER2. (The cells test 'negative' on all 3 tests.) It accounts for about 15% of all breast cancers and can be a difficult cancer to treat.
Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive type of invasive breast cancer in which cancer cells block lymph vessels in the skin, causing the breast to look 'inflamed.' It is rare and accounts for about 1% to 5% of all breast cancers.
42: Cancer that has spread beyond the layer of tissue in which it developed and is growing into surrounding, healthy tissues. Also called infiltrating cancer. In breast majority of cancers are Invasive Ductal carcinoma (IDC) which is a cancer of ducts or  Lobular Ductal carcinoma (IDC) which is a cancer or Lobules
